results.title: Katharine Hepburn: all about me: a self portrait
results.creator_credit: David Heeley, Joan Kramer and Top Hat Productions
results.brief_description: One of the most respected and beloved of actresses, Katharine Hepburn presents a unique self-portrait using footage from her many films, never-before-seen home movie footage and personal memorabilia. Hepburn looks at the ups and downs of her career as well as taking the viewer on a personal journey. Her candour and commonsense approach have been representative of her dynamic personality, independence, integrity, determination and strength of character. In a Hollywood which was largely dominated by men, Katharine Hepburn was a woman to be reckoned with.

results.title: Kathakali: the dance drama of Kerala
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, Ezra Mir and India Films Division
results.brief_description: Shows the State of Kerals followed by a detailed look at preparations for the Kathakali, the traditional all-night dance of Kerala which depicts the war between the gods. Concludes with excerpts from the dance.

results.title: Kath Walker: poet & activist
results.brief_description: A biographical documentary on Aboriginal poet and civil rights activist Kath Walker (Oodgeroo Noonuccal) who championed the cause for recognition of Aboriginal land rights, the right to vote, the right to an education, and to health care and equality with their white Australian counterparts. It took many years of writing and campaigning before Kath Walker began to see a change in public attitude but it was the setting up of Moongalba, an educational and cultural centre for both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal children, on North Stradbroke Island (her place of birth) in 1972 which was to be Kath Walker’s most ambitious and passionate project. She believed that teaching the young together in the studies of Aboriginal culture would assist in bridging the gap between the two races. In 1988 Kath Walker officially changed her name to Oodgeroo Noonuccal to more closely identify herself with her Aboriginal roots. She lived out her latter years on North Stradbroke Island continuing her teaching role at Moongalba until she finally died of cancer in 1993. Kath Walker’s legacy as a poet, activist, educator, humanitarian, writer and artist will long be remembered by both black and white Australia. Her published books include “We are going: poems” (1964), “The Dawn is at hand: poems” (1966), “Stradbroke dreamtime” (1972), “Australian legends and landscapes” (1990) and many more. The film contains stills, newsreels and archival footage (some in b&w). Narrated by Beverley Dunn, music by Nunukul Kunjeil. Includes Teacher’s Guide. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Kath and Kim: the series. Eps 1-8 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ted Emery, Mark Ruse and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Originally aired on the ABC in 2002, this eight part slice-of-life comedy series gives an obvious nod to the reality show “Sylvania Waters”. Kath (Jane Turner), forty-something homeowner and fashion and fitness conscious woman, finds her lifestyle cramped when her spoilt only daughter, Kim (Gina Riley), returns home after leaving her husband, Brett (Peter Rowsthorn) - again. Kath has recently embarked on a passionate new relationship with butcher Kel (Glenn Robbins) and marriage is on the cards. Written and created by Gina Riley and Jane Turner. “Sex”: Kim arrives home unannounced and Kath does not intend slowing things down on the romance front, much to the disgust of her daughter. Kim enlists the help of second best friend Sharon (Magda Szubanski), to find the recipient of the black lingerie she located in Brett’s drawer. “Gay”: Brett professes his continued affection for Kim but she suspects he loves Rottweiler, Cujo, more. Meanwhile, Kath begins to suspect something sinister behind her daughter’s breakup. Kim and Sharon try speed dating. “Sport”: Eager to get back at the women with whom Brett did the dirty on her, Kim agrees to play in Sharon’s netball final against them. When Kim’s skills aren’t forthcoming, Kath steps in. “Fat”: It’s fitting time for the bridesmaids dresses and Kath is mortified to discover Kim won’t fit into the dress. She orders Kim to shed the kilos and Sharon contemplates a career in marriage counselling. “Old”: Kath’s exhausted by the solo wedding planning and Kim thinks her mum is showing her age. She becomes paranoid Kel thinks that too and is losing his desire for her. “Money”: Kath’s worrying about the down payment for her pumpkin style coach and is adamant she’s paying for everything herself. Kim’s spending money like its going out of fashion. She does help out however by modelling for Kath’s pyramid selling lingerie party. “Party”: Kim’s organising Kath’s hen’s night - the night she never had. Kel’s reluctant at having yet another buck’s night, but Kath manages to convince him otherwise. Everyone is guaranteed a night to remember - at least parts of it anyway. “The Wedding”: Kath and Kel’s fairytale wedding ends in disaster with most of the bridal party ending up in the hospital. Told in flashback, the episode is a fitting culmination to series one.

results.title: Kath and Kim. Series 2 [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ted Emery, Gina Riley, Jane Turner, Mark Ruse and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Second series of the acerbic slice-of-life comedy show, “Kath & Kim” satirises the ambitions, aesthetics, language and aspirations of the working class. Kath (Jane Turner), a forty-something homeowner, fashion and fitness conscious woman, is newlywed to Kel (Glenn Robbins) the butcher. The bane of Kath’s life is her disgruntled, spoilt and indulged daughter Kim, a tasteless, overweight and overbearing fashion victim. Written and created by Gina Riley and Jane Turner. The announcement: Kath struggles with her libido and flagging marriage to Kel; Kim tries to win back her estranged husband, Brett. Inside out: Kim and Brett consider renovations, as well as procreation. The Moon: Second best friend Sharon helps out Kim despite her appalling demeanour; Sharon attends a class reunion; Kath plans a honeymoon. Obsession: Kath and Kel embark upon a new health and fitness regime; Kim struggles with her choices as a wife, humiliating Brett; Sharon takes up river dancing; Kath and Kel attend a plastic surgery clinic. My Boyfriend: Brett and Kim become separated in the largest furniture store in the Southern hemisphere; Sharon acquires a boyfriend; the netball final becomes a heated affair. Another announcement: Kim and Kath go shopping for the baby; Brett and Kim attend birthing classes, clashing over a range of issues. The Shower: Kath meets Kel’s sleazy best mate Sandy; Sharon plans Kim’s baby shower. The Hideous Truth: Kim awaits the birth of her child; Kath experiences flashbacks from her tumultuous first marriage.

results.title: Kath & Kim: series 3 [DVD]
results.brief_description: Third series in this hilarious satire about a middle class family living out their dreams in suburbia, continues the story of Kath and Kel, Kim and Brett, Epponnee and second best friend, Sharon. Episode 1: Kath has mixed feelings about the return of Kim’s Dad. Kim experiences the joys of motherhood. Episode 2: The ladies hit the races. Episode 3: Brett has a family crisis; Kath and Kel spread their (social) wings. Episode 4: Kim plans to shed the pounds. Episode 5: Sharon has a hot date; Kath becomes addicted to TV. Episode 6: Kath and Kim consider new career paths. Episode 7: Birthday celebrations create chaos in the Day-Knight household. Episode 8: A peak into the future for the residents of Lagoon Court. Special guest appearance by Kylie Minogue. Created and written by Gina Riley and Jane Turner.

results.title: Kate and Anna McGarrigle
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Derek Lamb and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Using a combination of animation and documentary techniques, filmmaker Caroline Leaf has created an easygoing mood in this informal portrait of the acclaimed singer-songwriters from Quebec. Highlights of the film include excerpts from their dibut concert at Carnegie Hall; a look at the songwriting/recording process, McGarrigle style; and conversations with the sisters, their supporters, and their critics.

results.title: Kataragama: a god for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Charlie Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
The story of how the parents of an eleven-year old Sri Lankan boy consulted an astrologer to help them find their son. The astrologer instructs them to seek help from the god, Kataragama, who correctly forecast the boy would be returned in twenty one days. Shows scenes of worshippers of Kataragama who thank him for favours received by walking through pits of red hot fire. Some hung themselves from butcher’s hooks impaled in their backs.

results.title: Karma
results.creator_credit: Shu Wang and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Stylish and artistic 3D animation explores the karmic implications of eating animals.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.
